handDesc.p: Halantas. Final M is a reduced and simplified ma, resembling a tick mark.

projectDesc.p: The project DHARMA has received funding from the European Research Council (ERC) under the European Union's Horizon 2020 research and innovation programme (grant agreement no 809994).

prefixDef.p: Public URIs with the prefix bib to point to a Zotero Group Library named ERC-DHARMA whose data are open to the public.
Internal URIs using the part prefix to point to person elements in the DHARMA_IdListMembers_v01.xml file.

div.head: Plates
div.p:
śrīmad-asanapura-nivāsa
vikaṣatānā tr̥r̥vbhuvana-mātr̥bhiḥ
trāṇāM calukyānā
sya naptaā vipu
maṇḍalasya śrī-viṣṇuvarddhana
sta-sāmanta-maṇḍalaḥ sama
pratihata-śaktitvāt sarvva-siddhaiḥ jaya
siśāṅhaa-vallabha-mahārājaḥ nātavāṭyāM Uccāti nāma grāme @@@pūrvva-sīmesīmāyāṁ sarvva
rddhi relluvaṭṭi nāma bhūmiṁ dvi-dvādaśa-khaṇḍikā-bīja-pramāṇena vaṁgipaṟu-vāstavyasya
Āpastamba-sabrahmpacāriṇaḥ kaṇva-sagotrasya dvivedinaḥ durgganandiśarmmaṇaḥ
putrasya mātr̥śarmmaṇaḥ padagavidaḥ putrāya veda-vide ṣachṭ-śāstra-vidyāya
mātr̥śarmmaṇe Asman-mātā-pitror ātmanaś ca puṇyābhivr̥ddhaye sarvva-kara-parihā
reṇa vaiśākha-māsi vyatīpāta-nimittea Iyam bhūmir ddattā. na kenaciT bādhā karaṇīyā.
Api ca vyāsa-gītāḥ ślokā bhavanti

traloka mahādevuka sammukhaṁ bu
ḍi buggi āṇati||

app.note: This word is written to the left of, and slightly below the level of, line 3.
All known grants of Jayasiṁha I mentioning Asanapura use the term asanapura-vāsakāt.

The reading is clear and may be a very bad corruption of the latter part of abhivarddhitānāṁ or perhaps vivarddhitānāṁ used in place of the former. If so, the intended expression would probably have been mahāsenenābhivarddhitānāṁ.
Compare tribhuvana-mātr̥bhir mmātr̥bhir abhirakṣitānāṁ in line 2 of the Timmapuram plates of Viṣṇuvardhana I.

Jayasiṁha I's grandfather was Kīrtīvarman, whos name, however, takes the standard genitive kīrttīvarmaṇaḥ in all cognate plates where he is mentioned. Given the probable continuation of this line (see the next note), it seems likely that naptr̥ was used here in the sense of "great-grandson", and the person mentioned at the end of line 3 was Pulikeśin I Raṇavikrama.

Although pu is partly lost at the broken edge, the reading is quite unambiguous. It suggests the continuation vipula-kīrtteḥ kīrttivarmaṇaḥ (as in the Timmapuram plates of Viṣṇuvardhana I), followed by a word meaning "grandson". However, this restoration leaves too little room for text missing before the extant beginning of the next line (e.g. śakti-traya-vaśīkr̥ta-saka-la-mahī, from the Koṇeki grant of Viṣṇuvardhana II). Reading viṣṇu here is not impossible, but less likely than vipu. In this case, the introduction of Viṣṇuvardhana would presumably begin here (and the genealogy would then start with Kīrtīvarman contrary to the previous note), but I am not familiar with a description of Viṣṇuvardhana I beginning with the word viṣṇu.

The beginning of this line suggests svāsidhārā-namita-samasta (Timmapuram plates of Viṣṇuvardhana I), while the end of the extant part suggests samadhigata-pañca-mahāśabdaḥ (Paḷḷivāḍa grant of Viṣṇuvardhana II).

I agree with NR that the title sarvasiddhi was used here. However, this title of Jayasiṁha I is never, as far as I am aware, explained with apratihata-śaktitva. That term is frequently used in cognate grants, but always in the form X iva apratihata-śaktiḥ.
The spelling of this name is nātavāḍi in the ARIE report and natavāḍi in NR's discussion. Other Eastern Cālukya grants use nātavāḍi or nātāvāḍi. In my opinion the ṭ is unambiguous here.
The ARIE reports the name as Uccāṭi, but NR is correct in reading the dental t here.
NR repeats this phrase in his discussion, interpreting it to mean twice 12 khaṇḍikās. This is possible, but not paralleled in any related grant that I know. I wonder if dvi is in fact deleted.

I wonder if the word intended here was in fact pautrāya. This would result in a more typical formulation of the donee's descent, and would also eliminate the strangeness of father and son bearing the same name.

Scribal omission is also possible here; the composer's intent may have been nimitteneyam. However, since related grants normally use nimitte in the locative, it is more likely that this is a case of non-standard sandhi, or possibly of inaccurate gender use (nimitte + ayam).
NR's actual spelling in his edition is kenacit bādhā (with a tb conjunct), but I assume that the original has a final T here.

This reading is doubtful. According to NR's discussion, the grant was made in the presence of the Queen Triloka Mahādevī. I know of no such queen, and even NR seems not to trust his own reading/interpretation, since according to his introduction, the grant does not contain any new unknown or additional information about the Eastern Cālukyan chronology or genealogy. If the reading can be checked against the original and a queen by this name is indeed indicated, then this is important new information. More likely, the correct reading is something else. One of Jayasiṁha I's epithets is trailokya-vikrama, which may have been featured or indicated here. As for sammukhaṁ, I wonder if the correct reading is in fact samukha (for sva-mukha).
According to NR's discussion, the executor was called Buggi. He does not discuss the damaged characters before these.

div.head: Plates
div.p: From the majestic residence at Asanapura. The grandson of Kīrtivarman, who the family of the Calukyas—who are empowered by Mahāsena, who are protected by the Mothers who are mothers of the three worlds who are of the Mānavya gotra —the son of His Majesty Viṣṇuvardhana, who circleThis was probably a reference to subduing the circle of rival rulers, to conquering the circle of the earth, or to perfuming the circle of the horizon with his glory. King Jayasiṁha Vallabha, who has subdued the circle of rival rulers sāmanta who prevails over all sarva-siddhi thanks to his incontestable power

The plot of land named Sarvvarddhi Relluvaṭṭi on the eastern boundary of the village named Uccāṭi in Nātavāḍi district, to the extent sufficient for sowing twice twelveOr perhaps just twelve; see the apparatus to line 9. khaṇḍikas of seed—this plot of land has been given by us, Jayasiṁha with exemption from all taxes, in order to augment the merit of our mother and father and ourselves on the occasion of vyatīpātaVyatīpāta is an astronomical moment at which the declinations of the moon and sun are of equal magnitude, related to the prediction of eclipses (). in the month of Vaiśākha, to Mātr̥śarman, a knower of the Veda learned in six śāstras, son of Mātr̥śarman who was a knower of pada recitation and who was in turn son of Durganandiśarman,It is possible that the text is erroneous here (see the apparatus to line 11); the donee's father was perhaps Durganandiśarman, and the donee perhaps bore the same name as his grandfather Mātr̥śarman. a knower of two Vedas residing in Vaṁgipaṟu, of the Āpastamba school and the Kaṇva gotra. Let no-one pose an obstacle to his enjoyment of his rights over it. There are moreover these ślokas sung by Vyāsa.
Many kings have granted land, and many have preserved it as formerly granted. Whosoever at any time owns the land, the fruit reward accrued of granting it belongs to him at that time.
A donor of land stays in heaven for sixty millennia, while a seizer of granted land and a condoner of such seizure shall reside in hell for just as many.
He who would seize land, whether given by himself or by another, imbibes the sin of the slayer of a hundred thousand cows.
In the presence of Traloka Mahādevuka. See the apparatus to line 19. The executor āṇati is Buḍibuggi.

Reported in 18A/1997-985 without discussion of details. Edited from the original plates by N. Ramesan (A), without facsimiles and without translation. The present edition by Dániel Balogh is based on photographs taken by myself in 2023 at the Telangana State Archaeology Museum, Hyderabad, collated with the above edition.Ramesan's edition contains an inordinate number of typographic (or other) mistakes. Divergence from my readings is only shown in the apparatus where it is meaningful and potentially significant, or where neither of our readings is interpretable.
